DOC.HEAD: 120 Rebels Get Prison Terms for Homeland Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A judge Monday sentenced 120 rebel soldiers to prison terms ranging from 3 to 10 years for their role in a failed attempt to topple the government of one of South Africa's black homelands. The group leader, Warrant Officer Timothy Phiri, and 21 other rebel soldiers were to be sentenced Tuesday. The homeland's Supreme Court in Mmabatho convicted all 142 defendants in October of treason or terrorism for their roles in the February 1988 coup attempt in Bophuthatswana. It is one of four tribal homelands that has been declared independent by South Africa. No foreign government recognizes Bophuthatswana. The coup was quashed by South African commandos, who freed homeland president Lucas Mangope from captivity at a soccer stadium and arrested the rebels, all members of the homeland's army. The Bophuthatswana News Agency said 92 of those sentenced Monday received 7-year or 8-year prison terms.
